newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-EU STUDYING SATELLITE DEAL WITH ENGLISH PREMIER LEAGUE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-EU STUDYING SATELLITE DEAL WITH ENGLISH PREMIER LEAGUE.

text.p: European competition commissioner Karel Van Miert said in a radio interview on Thursday he wants to probe a four-year exclusive deal between satellite broadcaster BSkyB and the English Football Association (F.A.).
But in Brussels, Van Miert said a distinction had to be made between formal investigations and the need to monitor all such deals. No formal investigation was underway involving BSkyB, he said.
In the interview broadcast on BBC radio, Van Miert said: "We have to look into the (BSkyB-F.A.) deal and also the duration of the contract."

Asked by the programme if he would intervene in the deal he replied, "We certainly will. We certainly will. And what should not happen is that those acquiring the rights will be in such a dominant position that they are going to impose the rules."
BSkyB sealed a 670 million pound ($1.07 billion) contract in June to buy the rights to transmit live all English premier league soccer matches for the next four years.
Last month Van Miert signalled his concern over long-term deals involving ever-larger sums of money in submissions to the European Parliament.
"There is this trend which seriously worries us that increasingly a few large groups can buy such (sports broadcasting) rights," he said.

In August the Commission launched a probe into a plan by the Dutch soccer association KNVB to give a new TV channel called Sport 7, which it partly owns, exclusive rights for seven years over premier and first division matches.
In a statement issued in Brussels commenting on the BBC report Van Miert drew a distinction between KNVB and BSkyB.

"...a formal investigation is presently underway as to the Dutch sports channel, especially as regards the seven-year duration of the contract, and not as far as the BSkyB-premier league is concerned.

"As to the BSkyB-premiership contract, Mr Van Miert said that this is part of a more general monitoring exercise related to the overall phenonomenon of exclusive rights on sports events," the statement said.
No one was immediately available at BSkyB.
